pullRequest.body:
Define translation of a function by an element of its domain

From LeanAPAP

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
I don't really like this code, but it is foundational for discrete analysis and I have found no nice way around using it. I would like to know @urkud's opinion as I am aware he needs translation for dynamical systems. Here are a few points of concern I am aware of:
* There is no multiplicative version. That's because I do not need the multiplicative version and wouldn't know how to call it
* This is basically an action by `DomMulAct`. The trouble is that it would be inconvenient to state it this way because I would also need to stick some `op` in there. And generally this action is wide-spread in LeanAPAP and I want custom notation for it.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [62d67df811](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16183/commits/62d67df811a7d2796fc0267127680608129dab10)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Translate`|567|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ comp_translate`
`+ sum_translate`
`+ support_translate`
`+ translate`
`+ translate_add`
`+ translate_add'`
`+ translate_add_right`
`+ translate_apply`
`+ translate_comm`
`+ translate_eq_domAddActMk_vadd`
`+ translate_neg_right`
`+ translate_prod_right`
`+ translate_smul_right`
`+ translate_sub_right`
`+ translate_sum_right`
`+ translate_translate`
`+ translate_zero`
`+ translate_zero_right`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Just to confirm, the `DomAddAct` spelling is `DomAddAct.mk (-a) +ᵥ f`
Precisely. And you see that I can't make `τ a f` notation for `DomAddAct.mk (-a) +ᵥ f` because then `τ (-a) f` would get "simplified" to `DomAddAct.mk a +ᵥ f`.

I'm OK with adding this spelling. In fact, it turned out that I don't need `DomMulAct` for the goal I was aiming to use it for, but it looks like people found other uses. Please add a lemma linking your definition to `DomAddAct` action and mention `DomAddAct` somewhere in the module docs, explaining that `translate` spelling is more convenient in many applications.

@jcommelin, both your comments are pushing towards `translate a f` being notation for `DomAddAct.mk (-a) +ᵥ f` (or maybe `DomAddAct.mk a +ᵥ f` against mathematical convention to account for the unwanted `DomAddAct.mk (-(-a)) +ᵥ f = DomAddAct.mk a +ᵥ f` simplification). Is this what you want?

I would be happy to switch over but, as previously pointed out, it goes against mathematical convention.

When you say "notation", do you mean `notation` or `abbrev`?
I don't think we should diverge from mathematical convention, but I also don't think I'm pushing for *that*.

Yes, I mean using `notation`.

Here are the four options I see:
1. Define `τ a f` as notation for `DomAddAct.mk (-a) +ᵥ f`. Follows mathematical convention, can be multiplicativised (eg `τₘ a f` as notation for `DomMulAct.mk a⁻¹ • f`) and also works for other actions (eg of a subgroup, on the right by using `τ (op a) f`). The not great thing is that simp would turn `τ (-a) f` into `DomAddAct.mk a +ᵥ f`.
2. Define `τ a f` as notation for `DomAddAct.mk a +ᵥ f`. Can be multiplicativised, also works for other actions (same as above), doesn't have an issue with simp removing the notation. The not so great thing is that it doesn't follow mathematical convention, but only to the extent that the action by `DomMulAct` doesn't*.
3. Define `τ a f` as a `def` which is equal to `DomAddAct.mk (-a) +ᵥ f`. Follows mathematical convention, but doesn't work for other actions and is not multiplicativised.
4. Define four kinds of `τ`-like notations as `def`s. Follows mathematical convention, but doesn't work for other actions.

*One could redefine the action by `DomMulAct` so that `(DomMulAct.mk c • f) a = f (c⁻¹ • a)`, instead of `(DomMulAct.mk c • f) a = f (c • a)` currently. What do you think, @urkud ?

Solution 1 won't be viable. Solution 3 is the one I currently have. Solution 4 is what you are pushing for, Johan. Solution 2 is what I see as the mathlib philosophy one, and it can be made to follow mathematical convention if we redefine the `DomMulAct` action.

Since there are some ope questions that don't have good answers right now, I'm going to merge this as is. When answers arrive, we can refactor.

bors merge

I agree this definition is valuable for the application Yaël and I have in mind, but I'd also like to hear others' opinions on its general value.
Other than that, this looks good to me.

Since there are some ope questions that don't have good answers right now, I'm going to merge this as is. When answers arrive, we can refactor.

bors merge
This probably shouldn't be global notation
Do you have a good idea of what locale it should be in?
I don't :/
This is asserting that simp-normal-form for τ is as far out as possible - let's add a comment to this effect.
This looks far too strong: I think `CommMonoid R` is enough
It looks like AddCommMonoid M is too strong for this one and the one directly below: just having zero (resp add) seems enough?
I think this can be useful in noncommutative contexts as well. So please generalize the definition.
But then do you want left or right translation?

right (pun intended), that's the question :grinning: 
We might want to have both. I always forget what left/right means: is the constant or the variable on the left/right?
Should we multiplicitivize this already? I wouldn't be surprised if we want to use this for `Units Complex` or `GL n` or something like that.
What name would you like me to use?
`leftMulTranslate`? Would that work?

pullRequest.title: feat: the translation operator
